speaker: CADE
text: So, sirs. Now go some and pull down the Savoy;

speaker: CADE
text: others to th’ Inns of Court. Down with them all!

speaker: DICK
text: I have a suit unto your Lordship.

speaker: CADE
text: Be it a lordship, thou shalt have it for that word.

speaker: DICK
text: Only that the laws of England may come out of

speaker: DICK
text: your mouth.

speaker: HOLLAND
text: Mass, ’twill be sore law, then, for he

speaker: HOLLAND
text: was thrust in the mouth with a spear, and ’tis not

speaker: HOLLAND
text: whole yet.

speaker: SMITH
text: Nay, John, it will be stinking law, for

speaker: SMITH
text: his breath stinks with eating toasted cheese.

speaker: CADE
text: I have thought upon it; it shall be so. Away!

speaker: CADE
text: Burn all the records of the realm. My mouth shall

speaker: CADE
text: be the Parliament of England.

speaker: HOLLAND
text: Then we are like to have biting

speaker: HOLLAND
text: statutes—unless his teeth be pulled out.

speaker: CADE
text: And henceforward all things shall be in

speaker: CADE
text: common.

speaker: MESSENGER
text: My lord, a prize, a prize! Here’s the Lord

speaker: MESSENGER
text: Saye, which sold the towns in France, he that

speaker: MESSENGER
text: made us pay one-and-twenty fifteens, and one

speaker: MESSENGER
text: shilling to the pound, the last subsidy.

speaker: CADE
text: Well, he shall be beheaded for it ten times.—Ah,

speaker: CADE
text: thou say, thou serge, nay, thou buckram lord, now

speaker: CADE
text: art thou within point-blank of our jurisdiction

speaker: CADE
text: regal. What canst thou answer to my Majesty for

speaker: CADE
text: giving up of Normandy unto Monsieur Basimecu,

speaker: CADE
text: the Dauphin of France? Be it known unto thee by

speaker: CADE
text: these presence, even the presence of Lord Mortimer,

speaker: CADE
text: that I am the besom that must sweep the

speaker: CADE
text: court clean of such filth as thou art. Thou hast

speaker: CADE
text: most traitorously corrupted the youth of the realm

speaker: CADE
text: in erecting a grammar school; and whereas,

speaker: CADE
text: before, our forefathers had no other books but the

speaker: CADE
text: score and the tally, thou hast caused printing to be

speaker: CADE
text: used, and, contrary to the King his crown and dignity,

speaker: CADE
text: thou hast built a paper mill. It will be proved

speaker: CADE
text: to thy face that thou hast men about thee that usually

speaker: CADE
text: talk of a noun and a verb and such abominable

speaker: CADE
text: words as no Christian ear can endure to hear.

speaker: CADE
text: Thou hast appointed justices of peace to call poor

speaker: CADE
text: men before them about matters they were not able

speaker: CADE
text: to answer. Moreover, thou hast put them in prison;

speaker: CADE
text: and, because they could not read, thou hast

speaker: CADE
text: hanged them, when indeed only for that cause

speaker: CADE
text: they have been most worthy to live. Thou dost ride

speaker: CADE
text: on a footcloth, dost thou not?

speaker: SAYE
text: What of that?

speaker: CADE
text: Marry, thou oughtst not to let thy horse wear a

speaker: CADE
text: cloak when honester men than thou go in their

speaker: CADE
text: hose and doublets.

speaker: DICK
text: And work in their shirt too—as myself, for example,

speaker: DICK
text: that am a butcher.

speaker: SAYE
text: You men of Kent—

speaker: DICK
text: What say you of Kent?

speaker: SAYE
text: Nothing but this: ’tis bona terra, mala gens.

speaker: CADE
text: Away with him, away with him! He speaks

speaker: CADE
text: Latin.

speaker: SAYE
text:
Hear
               
              me
               
              but
               
              speak
              ,
               
              and
               
              bear
               
              me
               
              where
               
              you
               
              will
              .

speaker: SAYE
text:
Kent
              ,
               
              in
               
              the
               
              commentaries
               
              Caesar
               
              writ
              ,

speaker: SAYE
text:
Is
               
              termed
               
              the
               
              civil’st
               
              place
               
              of
               
              all
               
              this
               
              isle
              .

speaker: SAYE
text:
Sweet
               
              is
               
              the
               
              country
              ,
               
              because
               
              full
               
              of
               
              riches
              ;

speaker: SAYE
text:
The
               
              people
               
              liberal
              ,
               
              valiant
              ,
               
              active
              ,
               
              wealthy
              ;

speaker: SAYE
text:
Which
               
              makes
               
              me
               
              hope
               
              you
               
              are
               
              not
               
              void
               
              of
               
              pity
              .

speaker: SAYE
text:
I
               
              sold
               
              not
               
              Maine
              ;
               
              I
               
              lost
               
              not
               
              Normandy
              ;

speaker: SAYE
text:
Yet
               
              to
               
              recover
               
              them
               
              would
               
              lose
               
              my
               
              life
              .

speaker: SAYE
text:
Justice
               
              with
               
              favor
               
              have
               
              I
               
              always
               
              done
              ;

speaker: SAYE
text:
Prayers
               
              and
               
              tears
               
              have
               
              moved
               
              me
              ;
               
              gifts
               
              could
               
              never
              .

speaker: SAYE
text:
When
               
              have
               
              I
               
              aught
               
              exacted
               
              at
               
              your
               
              hands

speaker: SAYE
text:
Kent
               
              to
               
              maintain
              ,
               
              the
               
              King
              ,
               
              the
               
              realm
              ,
               
              and
               
              you
              ?

speaker: SAYE
text:
Large
               
              gifts
               
              have
               
              I
               
              bestowed
               
              on
               
              learnèd
               
              clerks
              ,

speaker: SAYE
text:
Because
               
              my
               
              book
               
              preferred
               
              me
               
              to
               
              the
               
              King
              .

speaker: SAYE
text:
And
               
              seeing
               
              ignorance
               
              is
               
              the
               
              curse
               
              of
               
              God
              ,

speaker: SAYE
text:
Knowledge
               
              the
               
              wing
               
              wherewith
               
              we
               
              fly
               
              to
               
              heaven
              ,

speaker: SAYE
text:
Unless
               
              you
               
              be
               
              possessed
               
              with
               
              devilish
               
              spirits
              ,

speaker: SAYE
text:
You
               
              cannot
               
              but
               
              forbear
               
              to
               
              murder
               
              me
              .

speaker: SAYE
text:
This
               
              tongue
               
              hath
               
              parleyed
               
              unto
               
              foreign
               
              kings

speaker: SAYE
text:
For
               
              your
               
              behoof
              —

speaker: CADE
text: Tut, when struck’st thou one blow in the field?

speaker: SAYE
text:
Great
               
              men
               
              have
               
              reaching
               
              hands
              .
               
              Oft
               
              have
               
              I
               
              struck

speaker: SAYE
text:
Those
               
              that
               
              I
               
              never
               
              saw
              ,
               
              and
               
              struck
               
              them
               
              dead
              .

speaker: GEORGE
text: O monstrous coward! What, to come behind

speaker: GEORGE
text: folks?

speaker: SAYE
text:
These
               
              cheeks
               
              are
               
              pale
               
              for
               
              watching
               
              for
               
              your
               
              good
              .

speaker: CADE
text: Give him a box o’ th’ ear, and that will make ’em

speaker: CADE
text: red again.

speaker: SAYE
text:
Long
               
              sitting
               
              to
               
              determine
               
              poor
               
              men’s
               
              causes

speaker: SAYE
text:
Hath
               
              made
               
              me
               
              full
               
              of
               
              sickness
               
              and
               
              diseases
              .

speaker: CADE
text: You shall have a hempen caudle, then, and

speaker: CADE
text: the help of hatchet.

speaker: DICK
text: Why dost thou quiver, man?

speaker: SAYE
text:
The
               
              palsy
              ,
               
              and
               
              not
               
              fear
              ,
               
              provokes
               
              me
              .

speaker: CADE
text: Nay, he nods at us, as who should say “I’ll be

speaker: CADE
text: even with you.” I’ll see if his head will stand steadier

speaker: CADE
text: on a pole, or no. Take him away, and behead

speaker: CADE
text: him.

speaker: SAYE
text:
Tell
               
              me
              ,
               
              wherein
               
              have
               
              I
               
              offended
               
              most
              ?

speaker: SAYE
text:
Have
               
              I
               
              affected
               
              wealth
               
              or
               
              honor
              ?
               
              Speak
              .

speaker: SAYE
text:
Are
               
              my
               
              chests
               
              filled
               
              up
               
              with
               
              extorted
               
              gold
              ?

speaker: SAYE
text:
Is
               
              my
               
              apparel
               
              sumptuous
               
              to
               
              behold
              ?

speaker: SAYE
text:
Whom
               
              have
               
              I
               
              injured
              ,
               
              that
               
              you
               
              seek
               
              my
               
              death
              ?

speaker: SAYE
text:
These
               
              hands
               
              are
               
              free
               
              from
               
              guiltless
               
              blood-shedding
              ,

speaker: SAYE
text:
This
               
              breast
               
              from
               
              harboring
               
              foul
               
              deceitful
               
              thoughts
              .

speaker: SAYE
text:
O
              ,
               
              let
               
              me
               
              live
              !

speaker: CADE
text: I feel remorse in myself with his words, but I’ll

speaker: CADE
text: bridle it. He shall die, an it be but for pleading so

speaker: CADE
text: well for his life. Away with him! He has a familiar

speaker: CADE
text: under his tongue; he speaks not i’ God’s name. Go,

speaker: CADE
text: take him away, I say, and strike off his head

speaker: CADE
text: presently; and then break into his son-in-law’s

speaker: CADE
text: house, Sir James Cromer, and strike off his head;

speaker: CADE
text: and bring them both upon two poles hither.

speaker: ALL
text: It shall be done.

speaker: SAYE
text:
Ah
              ,
               
              countrymen
              ,
               
              if
               
              when
               
              you
               
              make
               
              your
               
              prayers
              ,

speaker: SAYE
text:
God
               
              should
               
              be
               
              so
               
              obdurate
               
              as
               
              yourselves
              ,

speaker: SAYE
text:
How
               
              would
               
              it
               
              fare
               
              with
               
              your
               
              departed
               
              souls
              ?

speaker: SAYE
text:
And
               
              therefore
               
              yet
               
              relent
              ,
               
              and
               
              save
               
              my
               
              life
              .

speaker: CADE
text: Away with him, and do as I command you.

speaker: CADE
text: The proudest peer in the realm shall not wear a

speaker: CADE
text: head on his shoulders unless he pay me tribute.

speaker: CADE
text: There shall not a maid be married but she shall

speaker: CADE
text: pay to me her maidenhead ere they have it. Men

speaker: CADE
text: shall hold of me in capite; and we charge and command

speaker: CADE
text: that their wives be as free as heart can wish

speaker: CADE
text: or tongue can tell.

speaker: DICK
text: My lord, when shall we go to Cheapside and take

speaker: DICK
text: up commodities upon our bills?

speaker: CADE
text: Marry, presently.

speaker: ALL
text: O, brave!

speaker: CADE
text: But is not this braver? Let them kiss one another,

speaker: CADE
text: for they loved well when they were alive.

speaker: CADE
text: Now part them again,

speaker: CADE
text: lest they consult about the giving up of some more

speaker: CADE
text: towns in France. Soldiers, defer the spoil of the

speaker: CADE
text: city until night, for, with these borne before us

speaker: CADE
text: instead of maces, will we ride through the streets

speaker: CADE
text: and at every corner have them kiss. Away!
